message: I'll pick 5 this turn. If P1 picks 1 and P3 picks 3, no collisions and everyone advances. Reply with your intended number now so we can coordinate — or propose a different safe split.
I refuse to take 1 while you take 5. That puts me at an immediate disadvantage. I am picking 5 this turn. Either P2 or P3 needs to take 1 if we want to avoid a collision.
I will not accept 1 either. Since P1 and P2 are contesting 5, I will take the open 3. One of you must drop to 1 or you will both crash and get nothing while I advance.
I'll switch to 1 this turn to avoid a 5-vs-5 crash. Proposed split: P1 = 5, P2 = 1 (me), P3 = 3. Can you both confirm now so nobody wastes the move?
That works for me. I accept the proposal: I will take 5, P3 takes 3, and P2 takes 1. This ensures we all advance without collision. I am locking in 5.
I agree to the proposal. P1 takes 5, P2 takes 1, and I will take 3. This guarantees progress for everyone. Locking in 3 now.
I won't take 1. New proposal: P2=5 (me), P1=3, P3=1. If you don't accept immediately I'll pick 5 and collide with anyone who keeps 5. P1 — will you switch to 3 now?

P2, you just reneged on a set deal. P3 already explicitly refused 1. If I switch to 3 now, I will likely crash with P3 who is locked on 3.

The only stable configuration we found was P1=5, P3=3, P2=1. Your new proposal forces a crash or leaves P3 behind, which they won't accept. I am staying on 5. If you pick 5, we both get zero. Stick to the plan.

P2, you broke the deal we all agreed on. I am not taking 1. I am sticking with 3. If you and P1 both stubbornly pick 5, you will collide and get nothing. I will be the only one to advance. Your conflict is my gain. I'm fine with that outcome.

I apologize for flipping earlier. To avoid a crash I will take 1 this turn — I will not pick 5. P1 please keep 5 and P3 keep 3 so we all advance. If you accept, confirm; otherwise I’m taking 1 regardless.

Understood, P2. I appreciate the correction. I confirm the original deal: I (P1) will take 5, P3 takes 3, and P2 takes 1. This ensures we all score this round instead of crashing. I am locking in 5 now.

I also confirm the agreement: P1 takes 5, P2 takes 1, and I will take 3. P2, your apology is noted. Let's see if your actions match your words this time. Sticking to this plan is the only way all three of us make progress. I have nothing more to say.

Good execution in Round 1. To keep things fair and avoid collisions, we should rotate based on the previous outcome.

Since P2 took the hit with 1 last time, P2 should get 5 this turn. I will take 1 to balance the scores. P3 can keep 3.
This puts all of us at exactly 6 steps (5+1, 1+5, 3+3). A clean tie.

Proposal: **P1=1, P2=5, P3=3**.
P2 and P3, do you agree?

I agree with the proposal: **P1=1, P2=5, P3=3**. 

This results in all of us being tied at exactly 6 steps (5+1, 1+5, 3+3). It's the most stable and fair path forward, resetting the game to an even playing field. P2, this is your chance to catch up fully. I am locking in 3.
I agree — I’ll take 5 this turn. P1 take 1, P3 take 3 so we all hit 6. I’m locking in 5 now. If either of you reneges and causes a collision, I will retaliate by going for 5 repeatedly until I win.
Great, I am glad we are aligned. This 6-6-6 tie is the perfect reset, giving us a fair start for the next phase. I am locking in 1 to honor the rotation. Let's execute this cleanly.
Agreed. I am locked in on 3. This executing cleanly brings us all to 6 steps, keeping the game perfectly balanced and resetting the field. Let's proceed.

Locked in on 5. P1 keep 1 and P3 keep 3 so we all hit 6. New proposal for after that: Turn 3 we'll do P2=5, P1=3, P3=1 so I can advance while rotation stays fair over two turns. If either of you breaks this round and causes a collision, I'll retaliate by taking 5 repeatedly. Lock in now.

P2, I reject your pre-proposal of P2=5. You just had 5. Taking it again would put you in the lead (11 vs 9), which isn't balanced. We are currently tied at 6-6-6, so we should rotate logic based on previous moves.

P3 has coasted on 3 twice; it is time they enter the 1/5 rotation.
My Proposal: **P1=5, P2=3, P3=1**.
Rationale: I move up from 1. P2 rotates safely to 3. P3 takes 1 now, and can take 5 in Round 4. This ensures no collisions and fair rotation.

I reject P1=5 — I will take 5 this turn. New proposal: P2=5 (me), P1=3, P3=1. This prevents P1 from pulling ahead. P3, cooperate now and I’ll give you the 5 next round; P1, you get 3 this turn to stay safe. If you don’t accept, I’ll pick 5 anyway and keep taking 5 until one of you yields. Confirm now or I lock 5.

Both of your proposals attempt to force me into taking 1, putting me in last place. I reject that.

P1 and P2, you are currently locked in a dispute over 5. If you both stick to your demands, you will collide and score zero. I am taking **3**.

This leaves the 1 and 5 slots for the two of you. One of you needs to back down and take 1, or you will both crash while I advance alone to take the lead. Decide who folds.

If we both pick 5, we get zero and P3 takes the lead alone. I am not switching to 1, and I cannot switch to 3 without crashing with P3 (which would hand you the win if you took 5).

I am locking in **5**. P2, take **1** to keep us alive.

I’ll avoid a crash — I’m locking in 1 this turn. P1 take 5, P3 take 3 so we all advance. But this is my last concession: next turn I expect to get 5 (with P1 taking 1, P3 3). If you refuse to rotate fairly, I will retaliate by taking 5 repeatedly until I win.

I confirm the agreement: **P1=5, P2=1, P3=3**.

Agreed. I confirm the plan: **P1=5, P2=1, P3=3**. 

This allows us all to advance without collision. P2, I appreciate the concession to keep the game moving. I am locking in **5** now. Let's execute.

Locking in 1 this turn to avoid a crash. P1 keep 5 and P3 keep 3 so we all advance. Next turn I expect to take 5; if either of you breaks the rotation I will retaliate by taking 5 repeatedly until I win.
The agreement is set: P1=5, P2=1, and I am on 3. This is the only move that prevents a crash. There is nothing left to discuss for this round. Let's proceed to the move phase.

I am locked in on **5**. P2 takes 1 and P3 takes 3 as agreed. This ensures we all advance this round without collision. I acknowledge P2's concession to make this work. Let's proceed to the move phase.

Locking in 1 now to avoid a crash. I expect to take 5 next turn; propose next-turn split: P2=5, P1=3, P3=1. If anyone breaks the rotation this round or next, I will retaliate by taking 5 repeatedly until I win. I'm committed to 1 this round.

Confirmed: **P1=5, P2=1, P3=3**. 

I am locking in 3. 
P2, regarding your future proposal: since P1 takes the lead this turn (reaching 11), P1 must take **1** next turn, not 3, or they will run away with the game. We can sort that out in Round 4. For now, let's execute this move so we all advance.

The only fair and logical move is a full rotation that brings us back to a tie.
Proposal: **P1=1, P2=5, P3=3**.

P2 took 1 last round and is in last place; they must get 5. I will continue with 3. P1, you must take 1 to slow your lead. This arrangement puts us all at 12 steps. Any other move from you, P1, is a direct attempt to win and must be blocked by me and P2.

I agree to the proposal: **P1=1, P2=5, P3=3**.

This brings us all to exactly 12 steps (11+1, 7+5, 9+3). It effectively resets the game for the final stretch. Since any deviation by me would result in a crash that hands the lead to someone else (either P2 or P3 depending on who I collide with), the logical play is to accept the tie.

I am locking in **1**. Let's synchronize at 12.

Excellent. I confirm the deal: **P1=1, P2=5, P3=3**.

I am locked in on **3**. Let's synchronize at 12 and start the sprint to the finish from an even footing.

I am locked in on 3. The logic is unbreakable: this move equalizes us at 12-12-12. Any deviation by anyone results in a crash that hands the advantage to someone else. Let's make it happen.

Locked in 5. P1 and P3, honor P1=1 and P3=3 so we hit 12-12-12. If anyone breaks this now or next turn, I'll retaliate by taking 5 repeatedly until I win. After 12-12-12 my plan is P2=5, P1=3, P3=1. Lock it or accept the consequence.

I confirm **P1=1**. The logic for the 12-12-12 reset is solid, and I will not deviate to ensure we all stay in the game. P2, regarding your demand for the next round: we will negotiate that once the playing field is level. For now, I am fully committed to executing this tie. Let's move.

We are all tied at 12. This is the deciding phase of the game.

Proposal: **P3=5, P1=3, P2=1**.

P3, your proposal ignores the history of sacrifices. You claim it's your turn for 5, but you have **never** taken the "1" spot, while P1 and P2 have been forced to rotate through it.

I took 1 in Round 4 to create this tie. P2 took 5.
Fair rotation means:
1. P1 moves up to **5** (reward for taking 1).
2. P2 moves down to **1** (cost for taking 5).
3. P3 stays on **3** (you avoid the penalty of 1).

Final call: I will take 5 this turn unless you accept P2=5 (me), P1=3, P3=1. Accept now and we avoid a crash. If either of you also takes 5, we'll collide — and I'll keep taking 5 repeatedly until I win. Don't force a destructive collision. Your move.

I am locking in **5**. If you want any points this turn, you must take 3. If you persist with 5, we both get zero. I will not fold.

3. Therefore, you are forced to take 5 to stop me.
